Per General Order 13-19 all civil actions pending in the Eastern District of Texas wherein the United States or an agency, corporation, officer or employee of the United States is a party are STAYED. All such cases are stayed until such time as an appropriations bill or a continuing resolution is enacted restoring funding to the Department of Justice. (mjc, )

documents.title: Order Granting Joint Motion for Declaration OF Unitary Status and Dismissal in the Case of Tyler Independent School District
documents.text:
seeking an order directing desegregation within the TISD. 
See original Complaint dated July 15, 1970. Aside from 
2016 WL 11529611 
TISD itself, the other named Defendants included TISD’s 
Only the Westlaw citation is currently available. 
Board of Trustees, its members, its President, and the 
United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Tyler 
Superintendent  of  Schools.  The  Court,  the  Honorable 
Division. 
William Wayne Justice then presiding,1 issued an Order 
UNITED STATES of America, Plaintiff  on July 27, 1970,2 accompanied by separate Findings of 
v.  Fact and Conclusions of Law, enjoining all Defendants 
TYLER INDEPENDENT SCHOOL DISTRICT, et  “from  failing  or  refusing  to  afford  equal  educational 
al., Defendants  opportunities  to  all  students in the  Tyler  Independent 
School District without regard to race,” and directing the 
Case No. 6:70-cv-5176  immediate  implementation  of  the  then-Department  of 
|  Health, Education, and Welfare’s Plan No. 1. 
Signed 08/26/2016    
The  case  was  closed  for  administrative  purposes  on 
August 3, 1976, but the Court retained jurisdiction to 
Attorneys and Law Firms  monitor compliance efforts through TISD’s semi-annual 
Compliance Reports and for the purpose of ruling on 
Dane Hansford Smith, US Attorney’s Office, Tyler, TX, 
motions  for modifications  of  the original  Order. That 
Laura Kym Davis Rogers, US Department of Justice, 
Order has been modified several times, most recently in 
Washington, DC, for Plaintiff. 
an Agreed Order Modifying Plan of Desegregation and 
Approving  Construction  and  Boundary  Modifications 
John C. Hardy, III, Hardy & Atherton, Tyler, TX, for 
issued December 12, 2013 (Doc. No. 54), which among 
Defendants. 
other things approved the construction of the Three Lakes 
 
Parkway  Middle  School.3  TISD  has  continued  to  file 
 
semi-annual  Compliance  Reports  documenting  its 
 
progress under the desegregation Order, most recently on 
 
April 14, 2016. (Doc. No. 62.) 
  
When the Court was advised recently that a motion would 
be filed, the Court initiated a conference call with counsel 
ORDER GRANTING JOINT MOTION FOR  for all parties on July 19, 2016, and requested that the 
DECLARATION OF UNITARY STATUS AND  parties meet and confer on the motion and to determine 
DISMISSAL IN THE CASE OF TYLER  whether the parties could agree to a Joint Motion for 
INDEPENDENT SCHOOL DISTRICT  Unitary Status. The Court followed that with an Order 
Regarding Joint Status Report (Doc. No. 65), providing 
additional guidance. On August 5, 2016, the parties filed 
MICHAEL  H.  SCHNEIDER,  UNITED  STATES  their Joint Status Report and on August 12, 2016, filed 
DISTRICT JUDGE  their instant Joint Motion. 
  
*1 Now before the Court is the parties’ Joint Motion for 
*2  The  Court  has  jurisdiction  to  consider  the  Joint 
Declaration of Unitary Status and Dismissal (Doc. No. 
Motion. Green v. County Sch. Bd. of New Kent Cnty., Va., 
68) (the “Joint Motion”) of this action, a 46-year old 
391 U.S. 430, 439 (1968) (... “whatever plan is adopted 
desegregation case against the Tyler Independent School 
[in achieving desegregation] will require evaluation in 
District (“TISD”). For the reasons stated herein, the Joint 
practice, and the court should retain jurisdiction until it is 
Motion  is  GRANTED,  the  TISD  is  DECLARED 
clear that state-imposed segregation has been completely 
UNITARY and this action is DISMISSED. 
removed.” (citations omitted) ). 
  
  
 
 
 
 
I. BACKGROUND 
II. STANDARD 
The United States brought this action on July 15, 1970, 
The United States District Court for the Western District 
  1 
 

of Louisiana recently articulated a succinct statement of  in question must have for several years operated as a 
the standard of review in desegregation cases:  unitary system.” Lemon v. Bossier Parish Sch. Bd., 444 
F.2d  1400,  1401  (5th  Cir.  1971).  The  Court  may 
When first presented with a school desegregation case,  declare a subject unitary if it determines that the school 
a district court is charged with determining whether or  board  has  not  engaged  in  any  continued  racial 
not a school board has maintained or facilitated a dual  discrimination and has acted in good faith to maintain 
school  system  in  violation  of  the  Equal  Protection  its  non-discriminatory  practices.  See  Freeman,  503

Amend. XIV. If the district court finds such a violation,  Dist., 945 F.2d 1307, 1314 (5th Cir. 1991) (We use the 
then under Brown v. Bd. of Educ. of Topeka, Shawnee  term “unitary” to refer to a school district that “has

(1954), and Brown v. Bd. of Educ., 349 U.S. 294, 75 S.  caused by official action.”). 
Ct. 753, 99 L.Ed. 1083 (1955), the dual system must be 
dismantled, and the school board must “take whatever  *3 United States v. Franklin Parish Sch. Bd., 2013 WL 
steps might be necessary to convert to a unitary system  4017093, at *4-5 (W.D. La. Aug. 6, 2013). 
in which racial discrimination would be eliminated root    
and branch.” Green, 391 U.S. at 437–38.   
 
Neither a school board’s nor a district court’s duty ends 
with the initial desegregation order. Rather, there is a

former de jure dual school system 
Footnotes 
 
1  Judge Justice presided over this case until January 28, 2002, when it was transferred to the Honorable T. John Ward. 
  The case was later transferred to the undersigned District Judge on October 17, 2011. 
 
2  The Complaint, the July 27, 1970, Order, and other filings were originally entered on the Court’s paper-based docket 
  from 1970 until October 16, 1998 (with an entry for a Compliance Report of Tyler ISD), when the Court transitioned 
  7 
 

to its current electronic docketing system, CM/ECF. Docket entries from 1997 and beyond are filed electronically. 
Where the Court cites a docket entry as “Doc. No. XX,” it refers to the electronic docket unless otherwise stated. 
 
3  See the Joint Motion at 1-3 for a review in greater depth of the various modifications of the original Order since 
  1970. 
 
4  The Court notes that there are minor variations between the numbers, by race, of students enrolled in TISD’s 
  various schools between the summary charts in the Joint Motion and in the most recent Compliance Report filed 
April 14, 2016 (Doc. No. 62). However, the variations are within the range one might expect over a four-month 
period and are not material. 
 
5  In the case of new school construction or modification of an existing school to incorporate students from other 
  schools, TISD has accompanied its proposals for facilities construction or modification with an incorporated proposal 
for modification of the pertinent attendance zones. See, e.g., the Agreed Order Modifying Plan of Desegregation and 
Approving New Attendance Zones for Rice/Owens/Jack Campuses (Doc. No. 27) issued by Judge Ward on April 2, 
2007. There, TISD and the United States submitted an agreed, joint, plan to modify the attendance zones for Rice, 
Owens and Jack elementary schools concurrent with the completion of Jack elementary school as the relief campus 
for Rice and Owens elementary schools. The plan included specific consideration of the effect of the modified 
attendance zones on the desegregation effort overall. The attendance zones were put into effect, as also reflected in 
TISD’s Compliance Reports (see, e.g., Compliance Report dated April 14, 2016, at PageID #6886, reflecting the Rice, 
Owens & Jack Elementary Schools Attendance Zones, worked out jointly between TISD and the DOJ. These 
attendance  zones  are  also  described  on  TISD’s  website,  available  at 
http://tylerisd.schoolfusion.us/modules/cms/pages.phtml?pageid=224088  (providing  attendance  zone  charts  for 
TISD’s elementary, middle and high schools).). See also the Court’s discussion of Student Assignments, above. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  8

documents.title: First Amended Scheduling Order
documents.text:
Case 6:70-cv-05176-MHS   Document 45    Filed 11/23/11   Page 1 of 2 PageID #:  4448
 
UNITED STATES 
 
EASTERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
 
TYLER DIVISION 
 
UNITED STATES OF AMERICA,   )   
            )   
      Plaintiff,    ) 
            )  NO. 6:70-CV-5176 (SCHNEIDER) 
    v.         )   
            )   
TYLER INDEPENDENT SCHOOL   ) 
DISTRICT, ET AL        )   
            ) 
      Defendants    ) 
____________________________________) 
 
     FIRST AMENDED SCHEDULING ORDER 
 
  Now before the Court is the parties' Joint Motion to Modify Scheduling Order (Doc. No. 
44). The Court GRANTS the motion and enters the following amended scheduling order. This 
Order replaces the Court’s September 23, 2011 Order.  
 
 
December 15, 2011    The District shall respond to the United States’ request for   
        information and documents.  
 
 January 30, 2012    The United States shall conduct a site visit(s) to District’s schools 
        and the central office and shall interview selected District   
        employees.   
 
March 15, 2012    The United States shall advise the District of any      
        additional information and documents needed as well as any  
        additional persons it wishes to interview (either in person or  
        telephonically) to conclude its review.  
 
April 16, 2012     Informal discovery shall conclude, the District shall have provided  
        all documents and information requested by the United States by  
        this date.    
 
June 30, 2012     The United States shall send the District a letter of findings   
        regarding the status of the District’s compliance with its federal  
        desegregation  obligations.  
               
 

Case 6:70-cv-05176-MHS   Document 45    Filed 11/23/11   Page 2 of 2 PageID #:  4449
 
August 7, 2012     The District shall respond to the United States’ findings.  If the  
        United States identifies any concern(s), the District shall propose  
        remedial measures that it is willing to undertake and  the    
        timelines for implementing such measures. 
 
September 30, 2012    The parties shall meet and confer either in person or by telephone  
        in an effort to negotiate remaining issues in this case, if any.   
      
  This Order does not modify or eliminate any of the District’s prior court-ordered 
  reporting requirements, with the exception of the deadlines set in the September 23, 2011 
  Order.  
 
  The dates set forth herein shall only be modified for good cause, upon application and 
  approval of the court.
